steps.title: Fry the chopped mushrooms and shallots in oil until they’re soft.
steps.content: Fry the chopped mushrooms and shallots in oil until they’re soft. Grease a skillet with 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of vegetable oil and set your stovetop to high heat. Toss 1 finely chopped shallot and 2 US tbsp (or around 15.5 g) of chopped mushrooms into the pan. Shift these around a bit with a spatula as you fry them so they don't burn or stick. [1] X Research source It should only take a few minutes for everything to brown. If you're using an electric stove, high heat will cause everything to burn (since it's direct contact). In this case, medium to medium-high heat is better.

steps.title: Transfer the fried veggies to a separate dish so they can cool.
steps.content: Transfer the fried veggies to a separate dish so they can cool. Scoop the cooked mushrooms and shallots out of the hot skillet with a slotted spoon and move them into a clean bowl. Give the filling a few minutes to cool down before mixing it with the other ingredients. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Stir the minced beef, mustard, and breadcrumbs into the fried veggies.
steps.content: Stir the minced beef, mustard, and breadcrumbs into the fried veggies. Knead 4½ oz (120 g) of mince beef in with the mushrooms and shallots. Then, add 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of Dijon mustard and 2 tbsp (15 g) of regular breadcrumbs. Keep kneading and folding the ingredients together until they're well-mixed and the texture is consistent. [3] X Research source Try pork instead of beef if you’d like to change things up. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Mold the filling into 2 sausage-shaped rolls that are 1 in (2.5 cm) thick.
steps.content: Mold the filling into 2 sausage-shaped rolls that are 1 in (2.5 cm) thick. Divide the mincemeat filling into 2 even piles. Using your hands, roll the meat mixture into a sausage shape. Make these sausages about the same height as the strip steak, so your “olive” isn’t overstuffed. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Place the filling “sausages” on top of the beef steaks.
steps.content: Place the filling “sausages” on top of the beef steaks. Arrange each sausage along the left or right side of your strip steak. These strip steaks will form the “olive,” while the filling will form the “pit.” [6] X Research source Get steaks that are about 0.4 in (1 cm) thick. If your steak is too thick, pound it with a meat hammer or rolling pin ahead of time to flatten it out. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Roll the steak around the filling to create a cylinder shape.
steps.content: Roll the steak around the filling to create a cylinder shape. Hold both ends of the steak with your hands and roll it forward, surrounding the filling with the steak as you go. Continue rolling the steak forward until it’s cylinder-shaped. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Tie both ends of the beef olives with string to secure them.
steps.content: Tie both ends of the beef olives with string to secure them. Pinch both ends of the rolled-up beef olive so the meat and filling don’t unravel. Then, cut 2 small sections of kitchen string and tie them around both ends of the beef olive. This keeps the meat from coming apart while it cooks. [9] X Research source Use butcher's or kitchen twine for this—it's usually sold on the meat or kitchen section in the grocery store. It's a common, inexpensive product. Use toothpicks in addition to the string if you want to make everything extra secure. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Sprinkle the raw beef olives with salt and pepper.
steps.content: Sprinkle the raw beef olives with salt and pepper. Grab a pinch of salt and coat the steak surrounding the beef olives. Then, sprinkle a pinch of pepper on top of the meat as well. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Fry the beef olives for 2-3 minutes until they’re golden brown.
steps.content: Fry the beef olives for 2-3 minutes until they’re golden brown. [12] X Research source Grease your skillet with 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of vegetable oil and set the burner to high heat. Place the beef olives in the greased skillet and fry them, shifting occasionally with a spatula, until all of the sides look golden-brown. [13] X Research source Feel free to cook the beef olives in batches if your skillet is pretty small.

steps.title: Add chopped onions to the skillet and brown them in the oil.
steps.content: Add chopped onions to the skillet and brown them in the oil. Chop up 2 onions and toss them into the pan along with the beef olives. Stir the onion pieces around until they look nice and golden. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Drop a spoonful of flour into the pan and then pour in the beer.
steps.content: Drop a spoonful of flour into the pan and then pour in the beer. Add 1 US tbsp (8.5 g) of plain flour into the skillet along with the onions. Then, stir 3½ fl oz (100 mL) of dark beer into the skillet—this prevents clumping. [15] X Research source Any kind of dark beer or ale will work for this.

steps.title: Simmer the mixture for 5 minutes and pour in the beef stock.
steps.content: Simmer the mixture for 5 minutes and pour in the beef stock. Set your stovetop to a lower heat, letting the beef olives simmer with the onions and beer base. After 5 minutes, add in 9 fl oz (250 mL) of beef stock to round out your sauce/gravy.

steps.title: Cover the mixture and let it simmer for a half hour.
steps.content: Cover the mixture and let it simmer for a half hour. Place a lid on top of your skillet and set a timer for 30 minutes. Simmer the dish for 30 minutes or so. At this point, dish up your beef olives and enjoy! [16] X Research source This dish tastes great with roasted leeks and carrots. Refrigerate any leftovers and enjoy them within 4 days. Transfer any leftover beef olives and gravy to an airtight container. When enjoying your beef olives again, reheat the dish until it’s at least 165 °F (74 °C).
